The show quickly establishes that Mob and Reigen's student-teacher relationship is completely backwards, which is often played for laughs (although this does stop being funny after the second time), but I really did like Reigen's character. He's fun to watch, he has some of the best lines in the show and he's shown to be very insightful and kind towards the end of the season. There are more characters I could go into, but I mostly felt either neutral towards them or just disliked them. Since I can't remember another character I actually liked right now, I'll just move on. I'll give this section a 4/10.


This show was honestly quite boring to sit through. While I enjoyed rocking out to the OP and watching the incredible animation (especially during fight scenes), that was not enough to save this show for me. The style of humor this show goes for gets old quickly (although I did laugh quite a few times), and it just doesn't quite engage me as well as I had hoped the same person who gave us One Punch Man would. I'll give this another 4 for enjoyment.


Overall, this show was just not for me. I can appreciate the series' incredible animation and music, but I can't say that the rest is anything special. The show is average at best. If you're looking for something that's just really nice to look at, I'd say this is a great candidate, but if you are looking for something more than that, I'd just say go rewatch One Punch Man (I know that I compared this show to OPM a lot and not everyone is okay with that, but the two shows are just very similar so it helps me show why I was disappointed by Mob Psycho 100).

Psychedelic and dramatic anime that easily gives me the "One Punch Man" vibes.
It's extremely similar to One Punch Man (what do you expect, it's made by the same author!). But for me, on how much praise One Punch Man has been given, I personally enjoyed this anime slightly better than OPM. I think that this anime thought me of a lesson—if you've been given powers equal to that of a God, would you use it wisely or use it roughly?
That's what Shigeo Kageyama is facing. A kind-hearted kid whose a reject (like most of us at MyAnimeList ;-;) but yields extremely powerful psychic abilities (similarto Saitama and his incredible strength). He has to find what life truly offers, because for him that his psychic powers are starting to get bored now. He hides this powers to the public, afraid of what he would do if he loses control of this potentially dangerous powers.\n\n
Mind the art style, but I enjoyed this anime. It is psychedelic, and brewing with creativity. Overall, I would give this a slamming 9.3/10. But that is just my opinion. ONE has given another masterpiece once again. Can't wait for the next series they will offer!

The story follows the exploits of the titular character mob and his mentor/employer Arataka as they take up jobs to help people get rid of evil spirits, basically they are sort of shamans. Like all action anime, the mob world is divided into people with powers and ordinary people. The people with powers like Mob are called psychics and the others, well they are just called people. Mob in particular is an exceptionally strong psychic and beneath him lies an even stronger energy which posses Mob when his anger reaches 100 level. While in this beast like mode Mob is unable to control himself andthus hurts everyone around him without any discrimination. Mob has vague memories of this phenomena and the time when he injured his younger brother due to one such break. Thus, Mob joins Arataka to help defeat evil and to teach from Arataka how to control his powers. Here, lies a catch as Arataka is not a psychic as he advertises himself to be, in reality he is just plain smart, more accurately, street smart. He uses Mob to his own advantage and occasionally gives him the cliched advises that any ordinary Joe could give. They battle the monster of the week where Arataka slyly makes Mob take the responsibility to defeat the monster and calls it training. Amidst all the advice Arataka says to Mob to never use his powers on ordinary humans or humans in general. This becomes Mob's Achilles heel as often in the anime Mob refuses to fight the antagonists as it is against his moral codes and ethics.  This is what the story line felt in the first third of the season. Even though I really liked it, I thought that this would be one of the old school anime wherein the MC just fought the bad guys and an evil organization in the last couple episodes. Bluntly said, I was wrong and wrong by a mile. A parallel story line runs here which sees Mob as an ordinary student struggling in his academics and athletics and in trying to impress his crush Tsubomi. In this story line Mob is shown as an everyday Joe himself in contrast to really strong esper. He realizes that Tsubomi is not impressed by psychic and looks for more ordinary strengths in her guy. Mob also is in awe of his brother who is pretty much the opposite of him. He doesn't have any esper abilities but is pretty much good in every other thing he tries. Mob exactly isn't envious of him but yearns to be able to stuff that everyone else can accomplish with ease, like eating without bending the spoon. In school Mob joins body building club to become physically fit to impress his love, his brother and more importantly himself. This according to me is one of the strong acts of the anime, as it genuinely humanized the usually aloof Mob. This is what separated the motivations in the anime from other generic shonen. Unlike the usual, Mob didn't really want to be the strongest Psychic in the word, nor did he care about it. All he wanted was to become a better human being and a person of whom his brother and he himself could be proud of.  In the second third of the anime and the major viewpoint shifts from Mob to his younger brother Ritsu. The story progresses from how an ordinary Ritsu awakens his own psychic powers. Ritsu is a genius and an all rounder unlike his brother. He is extremely smart, athletic and popular. On the outside Mob and Ritsu seem to be ordinary brothers who have that weird love hate relationship, but that's just the surface. Both Mob and Ritsu are kind of envious of each other. As discussed earlier Mob wants to be a person of whom Ritsu can be proud of, he is especially proud of Ritsu. He wants to be better at education and sports like Ritsu, and that's normal. Ritsu on the other hand is more than just envious, he borders towards obsession. From a very young age, Ritsu becomes painfully aware of the fact that Mob is special. Ritsu despite having it all, doesn't have the psychic abilities. He tries his best to cover his desires, and we as watchers might not even have known about his ambitions and desires, if the story had not shifted to his viewpoint. This is again one of the other stronger points of the anime. The rival in here got ample screen time and the creators gave him enough substance to flesh out a 3D character. Ritsu's ambition, motivations and emotions were made very clear, this gave a reason for him to act the way he did, he didn't just simply challenge the rival to become strong or to prove him wrong. This added an emotional depth to his character and to overall story in itself. Despite all of this, the problem with Ritsu was that he wasn't as compelling character as Mob. Thus, the slice of life esque story with Ritsu's POV felt like it was dragging. There was one episode where nothing really happens but Ritsu feeling angry all the time. The anime had noble intentions and tried to do something most shonen could only dream of,  though the shonen tag acted as a weakness here rather than a strength. The inability of shonen anime to have a deep meaningful conversation and the its inability to portray delicate human feeling without breaking the genre, left the anime to do this with only hard hitting visual cues. I felt that by this way, Ritsu insecurities were pushed to my face rather than showing it gradually and with some delicateness. Thus, the plot herein felt rushed and the feelings weren't portrayed accurately and subtly. This was one of the weak points of the show.


The characters in the show were quite well created. All of the characters you could see in real life, at least the human ones. The shy Mob, the genius Ritsu and slyly Arataka. All of these characters can be seen in almsot any group of people. Apart from Arataka, who was a bit exaggerated, both Mob and Ritsu felt human-esque characters. They had their separate personalities and motivations. These ambitions were something that most people desire. Mob desired to be a model student and  citizen, Ritsu desired something bit more complicated. Though, if the psychic powers can be substituted as just another talent, then it is clearly visible that Ritsu was jealous his elder brother. He admired his elder brother for these talents and wanted the same for himself. In that aspect Mob too was jealous of Ritsu's talents. This aspect was especially beneficial to create a more fleshed out character, as brother I am myself a bit jealous of my siblings skills that I do not possess. I have seen many other people wanting a talent that someone in their family has, but they do not. I felt that made their jealousy more believable and warranted when compared to other anime. Thus, the characters especially the two brothers are what separated Mob from OPM. The anime offered an emotional connect to characters and a window to their actions and thoughts. Other side characters like Arataka and Ekubo were pretty cool characters too. They added the humor to otherwise a standard action anime. Especially, Arataka with his wits and charm was an engrossing  and alluring character. He made the dull moments a lot less bearable and even when Ritsu was acting out of place and I felt the story dragged, it was Arataka and Ekubo duo who made the show a lot more fun. Thus, the show really hits it out of park with the character.


The art of the show was something that really took me by surprise. I am not really a fan of One's art style. I tried reading the original OPM and I couldn't get past 10 chapters without putting it down. I was really glad when Murata sensie decided to redraw it. Mob being One's lesser known work before the start of the anime didn't get any such version. Thus, the animators of the anime would have to work with One's style; this was a point of concern for me as I felt that the anime would have bad artwork. Though, all my fears were put to rest when saw the gorgeous artwork the anime had. The characters didn't feel animated, rather they felt like a hand drawn moving characters, like when you flip the pages of a book, though with a lot better fps. The artwork I felt was the best part of the show and really enthralled me. The opening and ending too was good enough and other themes like battle music too were not bad. Though, they didn't really stand out or increase the overall dramatic effect of the anime; yet they didn't feel out of place.


Finally, as I said earlier the anime was a must watch of last year and even generally holds out pretty good. What separates this one from OPM and other shonen in general is the emotional connect it offers with the characters while also excelling in the battle and shonen themes.

Mob Psycho 100 was a really enjoyable watch! 
The premise of the show is really interesting and I think the show does a somewhat good job of establishing the world. However, the show is slightly slow to start off and some things remain unexplained for example Reigen seems surprised there are other espers than Mob but everyone else in the world is not at all taken aback by Mob's possession of psychic abilities. Later on the show, some other characters awaken psychic abilities but it's never explained if just about anyone can do this or if those who do are special. These minor things andconsidering the show has a light-hearted aspect to it I try not to question it too much. The humour while not everyone's taste appealed to me cos it was just harmless fun.


While many seem to seem to find Mob's simplistic character design annoying or a flaw I believe it adds to the unique outlook of the show. Mob is a somewhat below average character there is not much to him besides his caring and polite nature and psychic abilities. The show follows Mob's journey of figuring out his relationship with his powers, and his want to create an identity for himself without them. If Mob were given any other talent I don't feel the storyline would have worked as well. Similarly, while the art style is slightly unnerving at first, it actually makes the show more unique and enjoyable to watch as different art styles are used in different scenes to emphasize the mood or atmosphere of the said scene. The opening track is actually one of the best I've heard.


Overall I think Mob Psycho 100 is definitely worth the watch.

This series borders on perfection. Right from the very first seconds of it, you realize that you're up for a bizarre, yet intriguing experience. Opening with a psychedelic-like fight between our psychic protagonist, Mob, and a bunch of colorful, bizarrely designed monsters. This gives us an insight to the very first thing we learn about Mob: he's practically invincible. Continuing with the tradition started by its predecessor One-Punch Man, Mob Psycho 100 shows us a story from the perspective of an overpowered protagonist.
Other than this and their obvious similarities in design, these two protagonists are immensely different. Mob is incredibly shy and reserved because of3 main reasons: 1) his powers make him feel like an outcast, as he doesn't know anyone like himself, and this makes him feel like they are a curse, a burden; 2) he develops an inferiority complex by comparing himself to his brother, Ritsu, who is absolutely perfect at anything he does. Where Mob is physically weak, Ritsu is strong and athletic; where Mob struggles academically, Ritsu gets perfect grades on a constant basis; where Mob is socially inept and awkward, Ritsu is popular, considered attractive, and has a position in the student council of their school. This antithesis, however, belies a more complex relationship of mutual jealousy between brothers, providing a chance to appreciate scenarios of brotherly rivalry, treason, forgiveness and love. And 3) Mob, in fear of his powers, has bottled them inside himself, and with this, he has ended up bottling his feelings together with them, leaving behind an expressionless boy who is seemingly unfazed by everything. Compare this to Saitama's awkwardness stemming from his utter boredom with his life, and his desire for action, and maybe a little bit of recognition.


The best aspect of this series, in my opinion, is its ability to subvert the notion present in a lot of entertainment forms that special powers mean someone is particularly special. This series takes that and flushes it down the toilet, as it takes psychic geniuses, grabs them by the face, and yells at them to wake up from their delusional fantasy and come back to reality, to realize that special powers are merely another human characteristic that sets us apart and makes us interesting, not a sign of genetic supremacy. No one represents this aspect better than Mob, who flat out refuses to use his powers for his own benefit or harm others with them, despite his immense natural talent, and resorts to other ways to grow as a man and earn the things he desires. He resorts to physical exercise, socialization attempts, and counseling from his mentor, the self-proclaimed psychic (read: con-artist) and overall charismatic and confident dork, Reigen Aratama.


The other thing that I find worth commenting and that is easy to observe is the artwork and animation. It reminded me a lot of short animations one would usually see on YouTube because of the colorful, rough, bizarre look of it, a style that works mostly for short works on the Internet. Seeing it here, in a longer form, seemed like a sketchy decision that could easily backfire. However, it helps set the tone for an out-of-this-world experience that bends and plays with our minds as wonderfully as only a master magician could. This series WILL toy with your expectations and beliefs, and as long as you're open to this, you will love what Mob Psycho 100 has to offer.


The only thing stopping it from a perfect score was my own enjoyment of the series. As much as I liked it, I failed to truly respond emotionally to the story and its various moments. I would attribute this to the fact that Mob's very overpowered nature took away the sense of true danger from my perception of the series, making this storytelling element both a strength and a weakness. Also, I watched it at a time where work and college stopped me from watching it with a clear, appreciative mind. I will give this series another try in the future, hoping an even more enjoyable ride.

Mob psycho 100 is a great anime with perfect jokes and relatable problem.
 The story follows the daily lives of a young esper, Mob, who has problems with making froends and being popular. We get to watch him grow from a awkward, shy boy to a good person, and it is so inspiring.
If you really hate off animation then you don’t have to worry about that. Anyone who’s really into anime knows that Bones has great animation, especially when it comes to the fight scenes.
If you’re looking for a comfy anime then Mob Psycho is also great for that too. The story doesnt focus tomuch on the fights but more on the characters. That’s why they feel so real. The story also make you care greatly for them.\n\n
Mob psycho 100 is for every awkward otaku who has never really had many other otaku friends because like mob has a hard time ‘fitting in’. Watching mob psycho 100 will insper you to improve yourself as a person, or atleast give you another great show.

This anime is amazing. Don't listen to any of the negative reviews that say otherwise, because they are blind by their biases--probably by how 'bad' the art is  or their high expectations how shounen anime 'should' be--to see how great of this anime is.
First Mob psycho is not your average shounen anime, which is really refreshing. It's about a middle school boy who has psychic powers. His employer Reigen is a con man who uses mob for his powers, which goes completely unnoticed by oblivious mob. Mob only has one wish which is to be popular-which may not seem like much for a plotof a story but you will be amazed at well everything ties together at the end. (I'm not explaining any more of the plot than this.)


On my next point, The plot is well crafted. Nothing is unexplained, and it's not too over board like some other shounen manga are.


The characters are well made which is surprising since I thought they were going to be cliche and flat--they were none of that. The relationships don't go as deep as they do in other anime like Naruto, but what can you expect from a gag twelve episode anime? It's a short series but we see how valuable each character of the main crew is. Yet, the relationship between the Kageyama brothers is one of the sweetest sibling relationship that I have ever seen in anime.


In addition, the humor is hilarious. It's not on Gintama's level, but it is something. I love it when shounen anime does that--going against the norm, and not in an overbearing way. The humor is just right. 


Also don't judge an anime by it's art, you will miss out on an amazing plot. I used to be like that until I watched ping pong the animation. It's art is so 'bad', but the plot is so simple and yet intriguing. After while you won't even notice how 'bad' the drawings are. The same applies to Mob psycho 100, however in my case I thought the art fit the anime. 


In conclusion, don't go into this anime expecting much, it's literally not like the other shounen anime. And this may or may not be your slice of tea, which you will never know until you give it a shot.

It was good enough to make me bingewatch it.... It reminded me alot of One Punch Man and thats probably bcs its the same creator.. ONE’s superpower to decorate trite truths with intricate details is as astounding as his ability to create identical all mighty protagonists. For half of the story he manages to deceive me into rumination about how complex is the coming-of-age problems of Shigeo are, how delicate and colourable the plot about his brother, and how surprisingly peaceful the anime about psychics is. Yet you can not swim against the (main)stream forever, ONE or not, eventually the boat of goodness will pick you up, exhausted, and carry you into explored waters of templates, banality and infantilism. That is the resolution of the deceptive beginning but, actually, whocares about philosophy? All you need is lov… khe-khe... battles. Late on the arrival, final episodes reveal the true genre of Mob Physho 100: shōnen villain smasher, with all the typical flavourings. I wish I could distinguish Mob Phycho 100’s implementation from countless others… but can I really? Can you? And though I slightly enjoyed originality of the animation, was almost charmed by charisma of scallywag Reigen and laughed at a few jokes, that is definitely not enough to leave a mark on neither my heart, nor my brain.


4/10

With the second season of Mob Psycho 100 airing right now, I decided to finally watch the first season and I have to say I am pretty impressed. Mob Psycho 100 definitely seems to do something unique with its art style, its characters and the several themes it has to tell.
Story: 7/10
Mob Psycho 100 is about Shigeo Kageyama (Mob) and his life as a psychic going to school and having a sort of part time job exorcising spirits with the con artist Arataka Reigen who is a self-proclaimed psychic. The story has a variety of different themes like what happens when people suddenly get alot of power in their hands with there being no one to keep their powers in check. Many psychics in this anime tend to think of themselves as the chosen ones who will need to change the world, because of their powers and get overconfident because of that. They then quickly get a reality check when someone stronger than them shows up, which often causes them to change many of their ideals. The story also gives examples of the bad sides of daily school lives, although the anime does exaggerate them a bit. Overall, the story, although pretty simple, has a lot of interesting themes and things to tell.


Art and animation: 8/10

If you want to have a taste of how the animation of Mob Psycho 100 is, you can just watch the opening as it uses a variety of animation styles and some abstractness in its animation as well. This continues throughout the show as, even though the character designs and the background are not too amazing, the show does seem to use very unique styles in its animation, which are especially seen in its many fight scenes. Overall the animation is not the best animation out there from a quality point of view, but it does have a very unique style and seems to use the fact that it is an anime very well.


Sound: 8/10

There are some very good soundtracks used in Mob Psycho 100, seen for example with its unique opening and some of its main themes like 'Mob Kanjou no Bakuhatsu' (Explosion of Mob's feelings). The show has a variety of different soundtracks for several of its different characters and a variety of different situations coming up in the show. The voice actors also do a pretty good job, although they did not really stand out more than usual.


Characters: 8/10

Mob Psycho 100 has a variety of different characters and the characters in the anime are pretty interesting overall. Starting off with the main character Mob himself as he is probably the least interesting, because he is a pretty bland character, compared to the other characters. He mostly lacks in expressing a lot of emotions and seems as very shy because of that. He does not think a lot about his own ideals either, as he copies most of them from Arataka Reigen. Another thing that can be annoying is that he is not very smart and basically falls for the traps of all the con artists he meets. Arataka Reigen, the self-proclaimed psychic is one of the most interesting characters from the anime. He is a con artist, but still has a lot of good morals and overall good things to say. He is also very sure of himself in his cons, which can often lead to some very comedic situations. Ritsu Kageyama, Mob's brother, is also a pretty interesting character. He has a pretty difficult relationship with his brother and develops a lot throughout the anime. The same goes for Teruki Hanazawa, as he has a lot of character development as well. His ideals he had about society change a lot after meeting Mob. Finally, there's Ekubo or Dimple, an evil spirit who gets weakened a lot by Mob and then continues to join the cast. He also causes a lot of comedic moments. Overall the characters (except for Mob himself) have interesting characters and some character development as well.


Enjoyment: 8/10

Overall Mob Psycho was a very enjoyable anime for me. It had a lot of interesting characters (especially Arataka Reigen), it has very enjoyable fight scenes with unique animation and a good soundtrack and also a variety of very comedic moments which make it a lot of fun to watch. 


Bonus categories: 8/10

-----

Comedy: 8/10

The show has a lot of comedy in it and overall executes it very well. Many scenes use the comedy as a part of the scene and a part of the character interactions, which make them seem very fluid. Sometimes there can be a few jokes in which it is a hit or miss case, but overall the comedy is very well done and really adds something to the anime.


Action: 8/10

The anime has a variety of action scenes in the battles between different psychics and the different battles exorcising evil spirits, for example. The battles use a pretty good fighting choreography and can often give some unexpected twists and turns, which can still make them pretty exciting to watch. The fight scenes of course will not be for everyone, but from a technical point of view they are pretty well made, use a variety of different soundtracks, unique animation and a pretty good fight choreography overall.

-----


Overall: 8/10 (7,83/10)

Conclusively, Mob Psycho 100 is a pretty interesting anime which has a simple story with some interesting themes, unique animation styles, a very good soundtrack overall, a variety of interesting characters who also get some character development and comedy and action which is very well done overall. It was also a very enjoyable anime for me. Now we will wait and see if season 2 can equal this season or can even improve upon it.

TL;DR:
Mob psycho 100 may not be the best of the best, but this anime definitely gets you hyped and amped to see the next episode.
Plot: 6/10
I didn't see anything special in the plot. It was pretty generic, but it kept my attention somewhat, so it deserves a 6/10.
Art: 8/10
The action and battle scenes caught my eyes a lot, and the style was very peculiar and interesting. A lot of the characters looked very different and specific, and this out-of-the-box thinking really struck it with me.
Sound: 8/10
The anime managed to deliver both an Opening theme and Ending theme that I found wonderful, along with the greatOST that accompanied the show throughout its scenes. I found myself singing along each time the show started. \n\n
Characters: 6/10\n
You have a pretty normal weak-but-op archetype main character, with a bunch of other common roles filled in by others. I didn't see myself getting attached to any of these characters, although I did get quite pumped for Mob's explosions.\n\n
Enjoyment: 8/10\n
Although Mob Psycho 100 is definitely not the best anime out there, it is captivating and fulfilling. I recommend watching it for its interesting style, great action, and intensity. It was a great watch.\n

Mob psycho is a great anime.
ART
The art is outstanding to me.
The use of Sakuga is used in an excellent fashion and they kept ONE's art style while making it look amazing, and I think by them having a more simplistic art style than the usual anime it's easier for them to animate well.
CHARACTERS
The characters are all amazing.
It's amazing how they could develop all the characters so well.
Mob is this character who has this one desire and that is to become popular and have charisma, but the thing stopping him is his powers and many episodes we get to see his backstory and what he hadto go through with his powers.\n
They give him amazing development throughout the story.\n
Teruki is also great.\n
They manage to develop him as this antagonist for Mob in two episodes and those two episodes they develop him greatly and what happens with him after is even greater.\n
Reigen is a great character as well who is a good and caring mentor for Mob even if he is a con artist.\n
Ritsu has one of the greatest character arcs in my opinion and I want you guys to watch it see for yourselves. \n

The beautiful thing about how ONE, manga author of Mob Psycho 100, creates stories is the evolution of characters - each has his or her own story, and the plot twists cause growth. It is also not new to this writer, as with One-Punch Man, to portray the main character as a simple, humble person with insurmountable power, unmatched by any other. What's amazing is that the setting of this series takes a completely new lens in the struggles a hero goes through. 
Story
We follow the narrative of Mob, an eighth-grader, who is very plain, other than his ridiculous psychic abilities. The themes thatemerge from the plot are mostly those of a typical Japanese middle schooler: puppy love, part-time jobs, clubs, making friends, sibling rivalry, and gang wars (oops). All these are juggled with the underlying elements that come about from Mob's powers: exorcism, supernatural battles, and organizations that seek world domination.


Though the above description of the plot themes sound quite ludicrous, the story was able to progress in a digestible way. The anime begins at a steady pace, with a dash of humor and a mix of seriousness here and there. Mob's life revolves around himself, his family, and his school. Eventually, he is pushed towards the world outside his comfort zone. Given his capabilities, and the responsibilities that come with it, what actions are he willing to take?


The plot was indeed enjoyable. What bothered me was that the ending was rather abrupt. Cliffhangers can be exciting and can call the audience to want more, but there were some unanswered questions (i.e. were there no consequences to Ritsu's actions?) that were unsettling.



Art/Sound

Personally, I am not a fan of the art or how the characters were illustrated. Though I understand it just adds to the comedy, I found it absurd that middle-schoolers from the Body Building Club look like old men. 


However, the fight scenes were admittedly amazing and artfully executed. The same can be said about the accompanying on-point sound track and effects. These definitely boosted entertainment value. 



Characters

For this portion, I wanted to highlight those who were of significance and displayed noteworthy growth. 


Shigeo Kayema aka "Mob"

Usually, main characters with invincible and inexplicable powers cause a plot to lack conflict and the hero to be one-dimensional. Mob, being the complex personality that he is, thankfully is not that way. 

At the beginning, he is shown as a loner who just wants the girl he likes to notice him. As the story unfolds, we see that there are two great things about him - his humility and his steadfast virtuousness. As mentioned, Mob has this ultimate prowess that no one can beat. Despite that, he views himself as a below-average person who needs to work harder than everyone else to amount to something. This inspires those around him to be better. Mob is definitely socially awkward, gullible, and needs to "get a clue." But it is precisely this innocence that pushes him to hold on so strongly to his ideals (to a fault sometimes). Backed by his power, he is able to protect those values he holds dear. Even if he is a simpleton with a lackluster personality, these qualities exude this special charisma that draw people towards him.


Arataka Reigen 

Reigen, the master of Mob, runs a low-cost psychic company that exorcises evil spirits and assists with paranormal concerns. He is the one who taught Mob to stick to all these wonderful ideals and values. The irony of it all is that Reigen is actually not psychic, but a con-artist who masters in deception and psychological manipulation. 

Many are angered at Reigen for being so two-faced and using Mob's powers to fuel his business. However, I believe that at the end of the series, we see how Reigen actually does hold fast to his virtues and deeply cares about Mob.


Teruki Hanazawa aka "Teru"

At the first encounter with Teru, he is described perfectly: a big fish in a small pond. As he is the only one with psychic powers in his school, he believed he was the "chosen one" and the best in the world. 

In the face of Mob, who has modesty, true talent, and power, he is humbled and changes.


Ritsu Kageyama

Being Mob's younger "normal" brother and the pressures he inflicts on himself, Ritsu has the most fascinating character development. In all other aspects one would customarily call exemplary - brains, brawn, good moral standing (he's in the student council), and social popularity - he has nothing lacking; Mob even looks up to him. However, none of these matter to Ritsu compared to his older brother's talent. He has a bro-con like no other, holding his oniichan as the standard of success. He is outwardly very kind and put-together, but in actuality continuously badgers himself with "why don't I have psychic powers." 

Once presented with the opportunity to taste the forbidden fruit at the price of his integrity, it's interesting how his power-drunk character affects the choices he makes. 



Overall

The series takes you through this awesome ride, with such a relatable setting and down-to-earth personalities. Just to reiterate, the plot forces that propels the evolution of the characters in Mob Psycho 100, coupled with the insane visuals and evenly powerful audio, is truly astounding. This really draws you even deeper into its spell. Though imperfect because of its lack of closure, I am definitely looking forward to the next season.

Now, I may be a slightly bit biased, considering this anime was the first I completely finished. However, in my defense, if I had done the same for an anime I didn't enjoy as much, I wouldn't be writing this review.
I don't have experience with ONE's other work (One Punch Man), but I'm glad I was introduced to him through Mob Pyscho 100. This anime is exceptional, and coming from someone who is very picky about what kind of anime they would even want to try out, that is saying a lot.
Let's first discuss the characters. The score I gave this particular piece is a10/10. The way these characters are written and presented are genius, to say the least. They each have very strong personalities--even the characters that only appear for a couple minutes in an episode. Meanwhile, the main characters are likable, even if you're not really supposed to like them. They each have a very unique charm to their personalities, something that--as a writer--is very difficult to achieve. Regein and Mob are irresistible and their relationship is incredibly fun to watch. Despite Mob being the exact opposite of what is supposed to be expected of a MC of this type of show, he is fun and lovable. You root for him and want the best. Each character is well-introduced, and you learn what they're about very quickly. ONE and Bones did an excellent job of creating and then interpreting/presenting these characters.


Next, the plot. I gave this particular section an 8/10, because it is a very simple plot line, but the little differences within it really make it stand out. The plot line follows a middle schooler nicknamed Mob, who is an incredible esper. However, he doesn't like his powers, since he'd much rather be improving himself to impress the girl he likes (who likes big muscles, rather than a guy with psychic abilities). He's mentored by the conman Reigen Arataka, who cares for Mob in his own way, all the while teaching him life lessons. It sounds like a plot that many people have seen before, which is partly the reason why I didn't give this a full 10/10. That being said, Mob is not like every happy-go-lucky protagonist, in fact, he's the exact opposite, which makes the plot stand out a bit more. His out-of-place personality pushes the plot out of the box of copycat shounen anime.


The art! I gave this a 10/10 because, wow, is this animated spectacularly. I will admit I like shows with different styles more than the usual anime look, but even so, the animation is never boring. We are very rarely left with ten seconds of a frozen screen where the only movement comes from characters' mouths, and if it is frozen, the animators and artists do it in a way that makes it stand out, so it doesn't bore the audience. Because the art style is based on ONE's original webtoon, the character designs are simple enough that more time can really be spent on creating interesting animation and explosive scenes. The use of different mediums also keeps the viewers on their toes, and it is, personally, one of my favorite parts of the show. The way they mix classic animation with different mediums helps make the scene's mood even stronger. Not to mention, it looks great (just take the EP, I mean, that shit is gorgeous!). 


All in all, Mob Psycho 100 is a great show, and I will never stop recommending this show to people interested in watching anime. This continues to be the only anime I have ever scored a 10/10 on MAL, since I've been watching more and more shows. I wouldn't mind if Bones did not come out with a second season, because these 12 episodes have done an incredible job of telling the story of Mob, and continue to entertain me even after I have watched it twice after my first viewing--though, I sure as hell wouldn't mind to see more great Reigen scenes!

Mob Psycho 100 is, in my considered opinion, a perfect anime. It does not have a flaw. I will go through the six review categories one by one. 
STORY: 10
The story of this season of Mob Psycho 100 is essentially about being a complete human being. Mob has unbelievable psychic abilities, but ever since he was a child, he's never been able to use them to get the things he really wants. His quest is to fit into his social environment and become a strong, responsible young man. Mainly, this is because he wants to date a girl named Tsubomi, a childhood friend of hiswho just doesn't care that much about him, them having grown apart as she fit in with their peers and he did not. From there, he gets a part time job helping a fraud psychic through the occasional real paranormal encounter, joins a club in order to become stronger, and has several misadventures along the way, most notably becoming involved with a criminal syndicate and having to deal with being a child placed in an adult situation. This story escalates perfectly, never bogs down, and spends every one of its episodes exploring Mob and his environment in meaningful, interesting ways. 


ART: 10

This show's artstyle is done a massive injustice by its still frames. Every animation here is perfect for the scene, with an absolute minimum of wasted screentime and moneysaving animation shortcuts. Action is fast paced and fluid, dialogue is visually interesting and well-directed, and story elements come as much from the visuals as the dialogue. The OP deserves special mention here. It's a visual treat,  laying the show's absurd universe out with surreal transformation cuts and plenty of spoiler-free references to later chapters of the manga. 


SOUND: 10

The voice acting is superb, the effects are evocative and unique, and the soundtrack is an absolute masterpiece. One of the best aspects of the show.


CHARACTER: 10

I'm not going to dive too far into individual summaries here, partially because there are a lot of characters and partially because I could never do them justice in a short-form review. If you want essays pm me, I'll write em. The main cast is complex, believable, thoroughly likeable, and surprisingly human for how goofy this show's universe and story are. The side characters are fun as well, with just enough going on to keep them fun without dragging the story away from Mob and his core group. No complaints, and special shout outs to two things: the dialogue, which is consistently hilarious, and the character Reigen Arataka, who is the standout of the show for sure. 


ENJOYMENT: 10

This show is, first and foremost, a comedy, and it is hilarious. The characters are funny without being unlikeable or unrealistic (in the context of the show's universe), the visuals are snappy and over-the-top in the way only animated comedies can really nail, and the setting is flexible and bizarre enough to absorb a hell of a lot of wackiness without breaking down. It's not quite on the level of Nichijou, humor-wise, but it lands every joke it tells and the psychic battles more than pick up the slack. They are gorgeous, weighty, consequential, shockingly brutal at just the right times in just the right amounts, and feel like the emotional climaxes that they (thanks to the framing device of Mob's emotional breaking point being shown onscreen as a percentage) literally are. ONE outdoes One Punch Man in a lot of ways with Mob Psycho 100, but this is the area where I think this show stands out the most. An absolute freaking blast to watch.


OVERALL: 10

It's perfect. Watch it. Watch it again if you already did. Read the manga for ONE's raw storyboarding. Listen to the soundtrack. Support the official release. It's perfect.

Disappointing waste of potential due to ONE seemingly forgetting what he's good at. 
To get it out of the way, Mob Psycho 100 is gorgeous, art style is fresh and pretty to look at thanks to well done line weight and good color direction. It has some of the most impressive animation since One-Punch Man, every episode has at least few moments of outstanding animation and fights are always breathtaking. When the show tries to be funny it very much is, there's plenty of comedy here both in visuals and dialogue and aside from visuals that's the second biggest strength of the show.
My gripe lieswith everything from episode 5 where show goes to shit and episode 11 where it gets back up. For pretty much half of the show's run time it forgets what it's good at which is being funny and tries to tell a completely asinine, edgy story about jealousy, fear of your own powers and not fitting into society due to one reason or another. None of those are bad by themselves but the way it's done is lazy and predictable way that doesn't add anything to the story and almost completely cuts out comedy. \n\n
That's pretty much it, funny, good looking show that for whatever reason forgets what it's good at for half of the run time.

When magic becomes commonplace it becomes redundant.
That is one of the messages this series has. 
Story: 7
Mob Psycho 100(now on referred as MP100 for sake of convenience) is in a way kinda brilliant anime, it redefines and combines genres into a big clump of fresh breeze. If you are familiar with slice of life anime's you know that they tend to be devoid of any major plot as they are meant to reflect "normal life", well MP100 manages to stay true to that statement while maintaining story arch common to shounen and action series. Although MP100 has story full of motives and end goal itmakes it redundant since the series ain't about the story but about growing up. Without spoiling any details I will say that there are many small sub plots in the series which will all intertwine in some manner and each one of these sub plots witness various characters coming of age story, Mob- kun's being in the spotlight. The "main story" is not that important and is pretty generic but it serves well as a medium to tell the stories that are really the important ones here.

Enough with story onto art


Art: 8

This is kinda subjective. I personally enjoy Ones art style a lot and the animations are made fluently. There is a lot of over the top animating in this series and it has strong graphical representation which conveys the mood of the scene well.


Sound: 8

The music fits the series well. I adore the opening music! All the voice actors are solid. I especially enjoyed Sakurai Takahiro's performance as the sleezy con artist Reigen and Itou Setsuo's as Mob.


Character: 9

This is one of the things where this series shines! All the characters, even though some of them fall into obvious shounen/action archetypes, feel unique in some way. You cry for them, you will detest them and you will cheer for them. There ain't completely one dimensional character in the series (on the exception of a few supporting characters) they have personality and most of them grow as a character throughout their limelight.

Although I must say Mob annoys me time to time but there's a plot heavy reason for that and I can look over it.


Enjoyment: 8 Overall:8

MP100 is solid series, not perfect but very good nonetheless. It's fresh and interesting I highly recommend at least watching it. It is sibling of one punch man that is for sure but it still has it's own stuff while being very smart  analogy about some serious important thing (this time growing up) disguised into more carefree action packed package.

Mob Psycho 100 is one of my favourite animes of all time. The only anime I enjoyed more than this one is Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood.
Yet, I have to say that the story and the characters are pretty mediocre. The only character I find pretty interesting is Reigen Arakata. He has skills in so many other domains, but why did he chose to activate in exorcism? I like Mob too, because he is pretty relatable in my opinion. The story is pretty good, not outstanding. I like the main characters of ONE`s works. They are socially awkward, yet indestructible, a combination that I absolutely adore.
The artof this anime is just too good. I really love the design of the characters and the surroundings. I also love the intro and the ending, which are just incredibly well done. \n
The intro is by far ONE of the greatest intros I have ever seen (haaa, i made a pun there, ha, ha... yeah, I know I am not funny). Mob Psycho 100 is made by the same creator of One Punch Man, and is deserving of its hype. I've seen 100s of anime, and let me tell you... This show is incredible, and personally, one of my top 3 favorite anime of all time. This show has a compelling story with many stand-out awesome scenes. It has world-class art. The music is good enough that you may end up listening to some of its soundtracks during your free time. The characters are diverse, interesting, and they fit very unique roles that go together surprisingly well. Also, Reigen may be one of the coolest charactersin anime ever conceived. This show really covers every aspect of an amazing show. If you haven't seen it, I highly recommend that you do. Mob Psychoo 100 is a must-watch. Why are you still reading this? Watch the damn show you scrub!

Mob Psycho 100 is an anime that at first has a rather unclear tone. Is it a comedy? Is it a parody? Action? Well, it turns out to be a mix of all these things. On the face of it, you have your standard overpowered shounen character, like in OPM (although Mob does have the weakness that his power can overwhelm him and then run out of charge for a bit). But the themes of this anime and how they are explored is where the true strength of this anime lies.
Mob hates the fact that his powers are the only excellent thing about him andso tries to become like his brother- good at more normal things like sports and getting girls. Mob's brother is jealous of Mob's incredible power. Reigen is a fluke clairvoyant but has strong core principles of non violence. The character development in this anime is phenomenal and the true strength of the anime. It's what seperates it from OPM, it's not a shoenen parody, it's a well done mash up of slice of life, supernatural thriller and character based comedy.


The art style is very unique. It's like it has been drawn in part with crayons. I find it to be refreshing and the bright colours are both appealing and suit the show as it allows for a vivid portrayal of the ghostly powers of the espers and phantoms.


The only things drawing the anime back are- the first three episodes for one. They are rather slow to start and many people did quit the anime because of them, missing out on the gripping action that was just out of reach to them as they did not have the patients. Sometimes guys, the 3 ep rule just does not work. Reigen is a great character but some of his advice to Mob was stupid, like his non violence that he stands by to such a point as to put Mob and his friends in danger, as he can't even fathom using violence in self defense. This behaviour is not really rewarded as Mob defends them anyway in such a way as to fool Reigen that he was doing it and with no violence. One last flaw is that some of the humour is very anime, if you know what I mean, and as such VERY hit and miss, but many moments also worked well, like Asahi losing his hair.


Aside from these flaws, this is a solid anime. I found it to be ONE's true masterwork and much better than One Punch Man, even if this one doesn't have the flashy animation to fool people into believing otherwise. A solid 7/10 from me.

TL;DR Mob Psycho 100 is gorgeous eye-candy with real substance to back it up. 8/10
Art: 10/10 The most unique part of Mob Psycho 100 (MB100) is the art direction. At the beginning, the goofy character designs have great comedic effect, but that serves later to juxtapose the beautifully rendered scenes of Mob's psychic power. The magic seems extra profound and powerful in a world that is usually oversimplified, bland, or hilariously ugly. Fights are stunningly well animated, and well choreographed for maximum excitement. The art makes the lighthearted scenes funnier and the serious scenes more powerful, and I give many props to this show forthat.


Story & Characters: 8/10 The story revels in good strong character development and an impressive set of morals and ideals that you wouldn't expect from the goofy outset. But like One Punch Man (perhaps even more so), MP100 is more than capable of delivering relatable emotions and character-driven plot. The characters have a wealth of depth to their personalities. They fall and rise and fall; they make mistakes and learn from them, and that is very satisfying to watch. 


Sound: 8/10 The Opening is very catchy and is a blast to listen to, but nothing else stood out to me.


A strong show overall. Would very much like a second season to keep it going.

Mob Psycho 100 was a simply superb anime from start to finish.  Hilarious, action packed and full of unique characters.  Throughout the first half of the anime, I thought it truly had the potential to make it into my Top 20 all time, and although it didn't make it in the end, it was pretty darn close.  
Three things make this anime great: 
1. The humor.  This is more an action anime than a comedy, so they aren't trying to constantly make you laugh.  There is some palpable drama in the anime and serious moments, but the humor is interspersedat a nice pace and the jokes really land when they do come.  


2. The action.  The art style of the anime really played well with the action scenes.  It's animated a lot like Kill La Kill/One Punch Man, which allowed the action to flow smoothly.  The fights were amazing, specifically when Mob fights the Shadow Boss and his first encounter in an alleyway with a Scar.  


3. Arataka Reigen.  This anime wouldn't be nearly as good as it was without Reigen.  A con man who has managed to make himself the mentor of Mob, he shines as the best, funniest character in the whole anime.  I would easily watch a spinoff with him as the main focus of an anime.  I had actually planned to deduct points off of the anime for its ending when it first started to play out, but it was Reigen's strength as a character that actually made it better than I think it would've been had it been a traditional Shounen type ending.  (You'll understand what I mean once you see the final episode.).   


In addition to these three things, the anime also provided a strong supporting cast, that I actually would like to see get more time if a 2nd season is ever produced.  Specifically the members of the Body Improvement Club and the Telepathy Club.  Dimple was also a stand out supporting character.  Normally mascots are irritating and needless, but the scheming evil spirit fit the story nicely and added to the anime, not subtracted from it.  The score was also outstanding.  The opening theme was especially beastly.    


Overall, I can't find much bad to say about it.  I'm not sure if the ending is going to be everyone's cup of tea, but it worked for me.  Mob is also a timid MC, but he has to be in order for the characters around him to work.  So, his flaccid temperament is synergistic with the plot and cast and works well.  


Overall, if you haven't watched Mob Psycho by now, definitely check it out.  It definitely earns its high rating here on MAL.

I have a little community of anime watchers where I come from. None of them exists on my friends list because I'd die of embarrassment if they ever saw one of my reviews. Anyway, the one thing that I always tell them is that Mob Psycho 100 is one of the most brilliant anime in all existence. But why? Why would I tell them this anime is worth their time, that this is my go-to recommendation for anyone who hasn't watched it? Why would I tell them that this anime should be a higher priority on your watch list than Full Metal Alchemist, Code: Geass,Attack on Titan, Boku No Hero Academia, One Punch Man or any other insanely popular 8/10 or above show on this website?


Well... The answer is simple. If I showed you a 5-second clip from each of the aforementioned shows and asked you to pick out a single clip which was the funniest, most badass and unique. Mob Psycho 100 is the only one of those clips that could fulfil all 3 of those categories and therefore would be the only logical winner. Yes, Attack on Titan has its badassery but I don't think it ever made me laugh. Yes, Full Metal Alchemist has its story but I don't think I've ever feared for the worst possible outcome. Yes, Boku No Hero Academia has its entertaining battles but none of them, and I mean none of them, could start and finish within 5 seconds and still possess the raw power of a scene that Mob Psycho 100 provides oh so well.



Story -

A la the nature of ONE, the story follows a very cut and paste theme of "a young boy with a hidden power gets mixed up in a load of sh*t". But, this is ONE, the revered creator of the Doomfist anime, which means it takes the utter piss.


Throughout the entire series, you'll find that Mob never once plays along with the story. All of the enemies are like "mwuhahaha I'm the big bad evil motherf*cker, there's no way you'll beat me, prepare for a fight that will last at least 40 episodes (*not including filler)". All while this is happening, bystanders are thinking "Oh he's finished now, they'll never beat Mr. bigbadmotherf*cker" or "Mob can't do this, he's gonna have a breakdown **EMPHASISED ANIME GRUNT**!!"


Now, if this was Bleach, I would have just described this week's episode to you. If this was Boku No Hero Academia, I would have just described Deku's 5-minute inner monologue that he does before a 10-minute fight.

However! This is Mob Psycho 100! And we have a protagonist who is as arsed with this fight as he is with watching every single episode of One Piece back to back. So what does he do? He casually walks up to the f*cker and flicks him in the forehead. DEAD.


This is the case with pretty much the whole anime, void a few instances where Mob's pacifist ideals come into play, and you'd think it would get boring. Actually, reading it back, if what I just described happened 13 times in a row then I'd probably give this anime a pass. The miracle of this show (and this is what ONE really is good at) is that this CAN happen 13 times in a row and be different and more entertaining every time. With added pieces of mystery and the little 0 to 100 buildup that Mob does from time to time, fights really, and I mean REALLY get you going. The show isn't about "how will he win?". It's about "How will the opponent respond when he's done getting f*cked upside under?".


It's also worth mentioning, as an aside, that Mob is in no way looking to get stronger (like every anime character ever). Instead, everyone thinks that he cares about his own strength but Mob just wants normalcy. Instead of asking "wise master Regan" what to do to strengthen himself he asks him how to get girls and make friends. Its a lot less entertaining when written in words but don't underestimate the power this has in making this story as good as it is.



Art and Sound -

One thing that you'll notice right off the bat is that Mob Psycho 100 has a very unique art style. One thing that I will say about Bones is that they're very good at what they do but this goes above and beyond. For anyone that has seen any of ONE's drawings, you'll see how that has translated into this exaggerated, glossy and all in all brilliant art style. Just pay attention to the little details, slight movements and emphasised frames and you'll understand... At least I hope you do cause I really hate writing about the art.


Let's talk about sound. While not as impressive as the rest of the anime, Its still f*cking exquisite. The anime opens up with a short and cryptic fight scene between a bunch of 'T H I N G S' but pay attention to the music. Even if you're not sure about this anime, watch the first minute or two and simply listen, because that's what you can expect and you can decide for yourself if you like it.



Character -

I think my opening paragraphs and story section did a pretty good job of describing Mob as a person, so I'll just skip right on ahead to the rest of the cast.


In Mob Psycho 100 there are 2 distinctive characters that I want to talk to you about. Reigen and Teruki.

Reigen is f*cking hilarious. Hands down. As a con man posing as an all-powerful psychic who specialises in exorcisms... and backrubs, he could single-handedly carry this show on his back. Without spoiling too much, let me tell you about what kind of person he can be. Towards the end of the series, Reigen challenges the most powerful enemy of the group. His opening attack is to pull out a coin on a string - everyone is assuming he's gonna try to hypnotise them. After a few seconds of peace and silence, he proceeds to uppercut the b*tch and send em flying across the room like a paper ball. He has no powers at all. He is completely outmatched. But he's an amazing con man and one of the funniest people in all anime and this scene demonstrates that perfectly.


Teruki is possibly the second most powerful member of the "good guy" team. His introduction was very interesting as he starts off as an egotistic shadow-leader with an obsession with his own importance. In short, he's a complete tit. Of course, as is true to my first paragraph, his royal slamjam twizzlerdunkerino turns him into a new person and he ends up being the key example of character development in the series. This may be worthy of criticism as this development literally happens in 2 seconds. He went from left wing to right wing in under 1.4 seconds. He also went through a wall...


Both of them together make up for the lack of personality that comes with Mob's character. I can't criticize Mob's monotonous personality as its who he is meant to be, is key to the story and you really can't notice it when these two are in a room with him. 



Enjoyment - 

I really can't put it any other way. I loved this anime. Loved it Loved it Loved it Loved it Loved it.  



Conclusion -

So that is why I recommend that all of my chums watch Mob Psycho 100. That is why it should belong at the top of their priority list and that is DEFINITELY why you should too.


Right then, now that I'm done with that I'll just read back through it and OH MY GOD HOW LONG DID I MAKE THIS IM SO SORRY.

It's a good example, that even with such a simple setting, as school, guy having a super power and falls in love with a classmate, can be fascinating. Everything about this anime feels set up in place, like notes in inspired piano melody. And here's why. 
First, even though this title is about supernatural stuff and physcic powers, feeling and memories of all the characters are always in the first stage. Powers, regardless of how mighty they are, don't matter, what does is how human you are, what person you are right now or will be. And that, I think, is a very valuable message.The story tells so much more than just Mob fighting with whoever. \n
Action. Mob Psycho is constantly hyping you with new enemies, or location, or with showing Mob's true power. And it doesn't hesitate with action sequence, I knew immideatily that all fighting scenes are gonna be marvellous. I couldn't help myself, but to eat episodes one after another. I believe if I saw this on japanese TV when it first aired, I would be dying to see the next episode.\n
Art and animation are incredibly creative. You can definitely see that even animators had fun drawing this anime. They used different techniques, art styles for certain slapsticks and emotions, it only adds to an amazing story. It's almost as if you can feel what characters feel through the screen.\n
IMHO must-watch, you're surely missing if you overlook this title.

Those series ended up being a bit.. underwhelming.
There are some similarities with one punch man, in the sense that there are people with supernatural abilities here. However unlike one punch man, this title is more focused on character development and motives, plus on the protagonist's character, and character's choices. I enjoyed action parts of the show, and character-development part of the shoe.
The problem is... the story for some reason took an unexpected direction in episodes near this season's end, and I didn't enjoy those episodes much. Didn't see the ending coming, though.
Additional details are below.
Story:
Aside from few episodes near the end, it iinteresting. Characters aresomewhat relatable, and are not cliched, although there are several one-time comic characters showing up now and then.\n\n
Art:\n
The show mimics original art by ONE. Meaning it is very different from standard anime - character's are drawn in simplistic/rough fashion, and some of the background characters may be downright ugly and may resemble unskilled drawings. However, you quickly get used to this style, and it works great in action scenes. It is not Kemonozume, but it is fairly unusual. Still all the important characters are quite well drawn, despite the overall "rough" style.\n\n
Sound:\n
Very entertaining/interesting intro song. Overal music is very good, without any cliched themes.\n\n
Character:\n
As mentioned earlier, they're relatable and undergo character development, although some of them serve as comic relieff. Characters aren't as simple as they would seem at a first glance, and over the time they slowly develop, plus you start learning new sides of their character.\n\n
Overall:\n
It is good, but I expected more after seeing first episodes. It is definitely worth checking out, and probably would work best if you watch the whole season in one sitting.

Possibly the best series that has ever come from Bones studios, Mob Psycho 100 is the perfect concoction of funny, heartfelt, and action-packed anime. Following the unlikely hero and protagonist, Shigeo Kageyama, aka Mob, makes this series all the more enjoyable; Mob Psycho 100 is the epitome of character development across the board, so be prepared to fall in love with every character who appears on screen! With gorgeous and smooth yet effective animation, amazing voice acting in both Japanese and English, and lighthearted comedy, Mob Psycho 100 is enjoyable for all fans of anime. Trust me, you've never seen anything like this before! Ihighly, highly recommend it!

As with One Punch Man, characterization is a strength while the story is a weakness. But this review is about Mob Psycho 100, so let's get started with that.
Story: 6 for Fair
The same format as OPM. In the beginning, there's a teacher and a student. The student follows the teacher, even though said teacher has nothing to give the student. They defeat some things because they profit from it and want to help others. (In OPM there's rankings and in MP100 there's money.) And there's more of a story at the end, something that links the last few episodes and ties them together as moreof a sequential progression. Nothing about it was too new or innovative, but it moved.


Art: 8 for Very Good


Mob Psycho 100's art is also incredibly experimental in comparison to OPM. With techniques like paint-on-glass animation, the paranormal scenes can contrast the more realistic ones. It's beautiful to GIF and beautiful to watch. 


Sound: 7 for Good


There's not really much to remark upon here. I did appreciate the musical scores during or approaching battle scenes, but this was more towards the end of the series.


Character: 7 for Good


The dynamic does not attach itself to any new format: Mob/Reigen can just be seen as Genos/Saitama, albeit with different motivations. (Reigen relies on Mob for profit and possible emotional fulfillment.)


And Mob bears many similarities to Saitama. He is not concerned with power, but he is concerned with finding a purpose in life. He is almost effortlessly strong. His indifference is not unique. However, Ritsu's relationship with Mob makes him different from Saitama. Ritsu humanizes Mob, in a way. The Body Improvement Club and Tsubomi also help with this. 


I truly loved Reigen. While Mob doesn't exactly need a father figure, Reigen is receptive to his calls for help. I commend the timing of the Mob/Reigen backstory. It's not exactly revolutionary, but it was more interesting than having it at the beginning.


Enjoyment and Overall: 8 for Very Good


I really did enjoy Mob Psycho 100. It's a good twelve episode stretch where you're introduced to solid characters and stimulating visuals. However, the story is lacking. Character development and relationships were the things to attach me. If you're looking for a better story than OPM, maybe MP100 isn't for you.


I recommend Noragami to anyone who's enjoyed this one, as well. It reminds me of Noragami in terms of the "there's always an exception to death" rule, and just the overall theme and look of spirits.

So... Let me just say I went to this with some expectations - having watched One Punch Man (Season 1) and hearing about how much Mob Psycho 100 lived up to the hype and learning the hard way it kinda doesn't...? Sorry guys, if you wanted me to start gushing about this show left and right, this review ain't gonna be about that.
I'll try to make this simple and concise: psychic abilities aren't that new a concept, nor are they original. But fine, I can let that pass. The author just needed a new way to make stories about overpowered characters - and don't thinkI'm throwing this at the author's face: it works. Mostly, at least. With One Punch Man, it did. And I'm sorry if y'all don't like comparisons but it's very easy to difficult not to compare the author's different works, specially when they're this similar.


Let's do this by parts.


STORY: It's not that special, but not that bad, either. The characters are the redeeming quality, because I believe the author at least tried to make them feel real, gave 'em a moral compass or lack-there-of, etc. The story is highly bland if you look at it from an entertaining standpoint, of course, it's all for the sake of comedy.


I'm sorry, but the only CLOSE THING I did to laughing while watching this show was smiling when the main character had a wholesome moment or when those "IMMA-KILL-THIS-KID-HERE-AND-NOW" followed by the villain being brutally crushed by the protagonists moments hit. Those were funny, truly never gets old. This may be debatable, but I believe that's why One Punch Man is so appreciated, too. But that's another show, of course, let's keep our eyes on this one.


CHARACTERS: The one genuinely funny character? Reigen. The wholesome ones? Mob and Ritsu. The good ones? Dimple, the blond guy (sorry, can't remember his name) and the Bodybuilding Group Guys.


SOUND: For me, the opening got stale after 1 listen. I didn't even bother to listen to the whole ending. Not going to shit on either, though.


ART: The art is fairly good but highly reminiscent of One Punch Man. Not to say it doesn't look good, but it definitely has that "more of the same" vibe. Other than that, the animation MOSTLY holds up. Here's the thing: I get that some moments are pure and raw power and action, but some action sequences were ruined because of bad direction. Episodes 6-7 have examples of that. Once again, it's mostly my opinion. 


ENJOYMENT: Watched it till the end for the characters. I haven't made up my mind about watching season 2. It was definitely entertaining, but I can't say the rating on this site is that accurate, though.


Hope this review helps ya!

To be honest, I was unsure of this anime at first, but my motto is to give everything a chance. So, I did and man, am I glad I did! While the art style is a bit abstract, it's not bad by any means. The animation quality was great and there was good character development of the lead characters. Mob Psycho 100 is a perfect combination of funny and exciting with a little bit of wtf added to the mix. If I had to judge this anime using only one word, it would definitely have to be "bruh" lol. Totally recommend.

Mob Psycho 100 i think is the 2nd best anime of 2016 just bested by Shouwa Genroku Rakugo Shinjuu. Here are my thoughts (spoiler warning ahead)
Story 9
The story of Mob Psycho 100 is about a boy named Shigeo Kageyama commonly referred to as Mob, Mob has supernatural psychic powers. Mob works under Arataka Reigen whom Mob calls his master thanks to Reigen giving him life lessons, Reigen is an "exorcist" but is actually a fake and uses Mob to fight the spirits with his powers but also trying to keep Mob in check so he wouldn't go out of control with his powers because whenhe reaches 100% he would go berzerk and loses control of his powers going in a blind rage in the process.


The story of Mob Psycho 100 i think is pretty fucking amazing, the pacing of the story is also pretty great and it's pretty tough getting only 12 episodes for a action supernatural anime without it getting rushed but in the end it's paced perfectly, if i got to say one thing i dislike it's probably the ending, it's pretty sequel baiting but that's it, the story is pretty great


Art 10


The art for Mob Psycho 100 is vivid and amazing. In my opinion this has got to be the best show that Bones has ever animated. Every single frame looks smooth and beautiful, the interaction between characters are also really well animated with the face expressions smoothly animated. The action scenes are really where it's at in terms of animation, Every single thing the characters do in the fight scenes are amazingly animated and choreographed with the supernatural techniques looking as beautiful as they can be and the opening and ending animation are amazing as fuck


Sound 8


The sound of Mob Psycho is pretty good but i find the soundtrack excluding the OP and ED kind of lacking but that's a minor complaint, the sound of the anime is great with the action scenes again being the high point with the sound design


Character 10


Every single character in the anime is great, but my highlight goes to Arataka Reigen, he is just so well developed from being a con artist that you would probably hate in the beginning but once Mob tells all these stories about him giving Mob superb advice for dealing things in life you can tell he's more than meets the eye, that doesn't mean that Mob the main character isn't great he's fucking amazing, especially during the second half of the show. The main supporting characters are also pretty good with Mob's little brother, Hanazawa and Ekubo being the highlights for the main supporting characters (the main characters other than Mob and Reigen)


Enjoyment 10


I don't know how to explain how i enjoyed the show so much but my god i did


Overall 10


I think Mob Psycho 100 might be the most fun i had last year with the show being great in every way possible in my perspective so i'll probably have a blast again rewatching this show

I consider mob psycho 100 better than one punch man in some aspects, (which does not mean I do not like any of the 2) to start psycho 100 mob (MP 100) is less repetitive than OPM, but has no objective
also 100 has a plot, (unlike one punch man) but puts comedy scenes in serious moments which means that you can not take the series in cerium, the protagonist has no personality and the music is forgettable
(Not to mention that the series has a joke that is repeated too much like OPM)
conclusion: it's better than OPM but it's still mediocre

Mob Psycho 100 is, in short, one punch man but a little different.
It is recommended if you can enjoy/aren't troubled with any of these:
• Comedy
• Blood
• Nudity (nothing too lewd.)
If you do, then you might enjoy this anime.
------------------------------------------------------
• Story
It isn't too interesting, it isn't too grand, but at the same time, you just want to finish it. It isn't a confusing story and you'll pick up on it easily.
• Art
You may think that it'll look like how One Punch Man was, but the art in Mob Psycho 100 is completely different and is actually quite unique.
• Sound
Not too many errors in the episodes, the musicin the anime are really good.\n\n
• Character\n\n
Characters, like how everyone else sees it, seems like they're a copy and paste of Saitama and Genos, but that is just their appearance; the attitude the characters have makes their presentation fitting for them. \n\n
