Mob Psycho 100 is the adaptation of the second most famous webcomic of the One Punch Man creator ONE. The characters are the main selling point. Mob is a shy 14 boy who just wants to better himself and doesnt wastes his time in some school club. Reigen is the most clever and charismatic chracter ive seen in some time. they work together perfectly. The villians of the show all think that they are some kind of hot shit because of their abilities, bhut their are mostly normal humans with some weird complexes. The supporting chrakters are really good and dont feel useless. 
The animationis one of the best animations that exist right now. Its refreshing and innovative. The story is a typical "save the world" story with some slice of life elements, but it mainly focuses on Mob and his character deveplopment.\n\n
10/10 Must watch

Overall, I think Mob Psycho 100 is a really enjoyable show. 
With a great art style, funny characters, and incredible action, I think most people will enjoy watching it just as much as I did.
My favourite parts of this show include the sound design, which was very good; especially the fight themes and OP. The animation is really incredible as well, and paired up with the bright and unique art style, this is one of the best looking anime out there in my opinion.
I've heard many people say that this show is too similar to One Punch Man, and there are clear similarities, such asthe character design of manga artist One, creator of both Mob Psycho 100 and OPM, and the concept of an overpowered main character. \n
Personally, I do not think this detracted from my enjoyment, as the two shows vary quite a lot in the themes they tackle, and don't end up feeling too similar.\n\n
Overall this show is a solid 9/10 from me. I'd recommend it to anyone.

The only thing that stopped me from watching this earlier was because I just didn't know about it. If I'd have known one of my favourite content creators had released a new anime, I would have jumped on it from day one (heh).
STORY: 7
The actual storyline-story doesn't show up until halfway through the season, but up to that point, I was okay with it just being a slice-of-life anime about a kid with psychic powers. The meat of the plot is your standard bad guys doing bad guy things, but with something bigger possibly brewing under the surface (and the ever-nearing Season 2), I hopeI can look forward to something a bit more unique later on.


ART: 9


The art is basically lifted right from the manga (with a few necessary touch-ups), and it fits very well. The dynamic lighting makes the sort of simplistic art style stand out from other anime that have the "rough edges" style.


Sound: 8


As I said above, I watched the English dub. I can't complain about any of the character's voices; they fit them all very well. I may give the sound an 8 overall, but if I were to rate the opening, I would have to give it higher than a 10! It's a top contender for my favourite anime OP of all time (so far).


CHARACTER: 8


This is where the show really shines, for the most part. The main characters are so fun and distinct. But the best part of the writing is that the character flaws practically write the story. The situations they get into, and how the situation plays out, depends on their personalities; I don't think anyone does anything remotely out of character. However, as great as the main characters are, the side characters are really left on the sidelines, with almost no development whatsoever. I get that there's not a whole lot you can do in 12 episodes (and maybe I'm a bit spoiled since MHA deals with its supporting characters very well), but with some characters, they hint at a potential story element with them, then leave them alone for a long time. It's a little disappointing, but hopefully they'll get their own chance in the limelight next season.


ENJOYMENT: 9


I binged this with a friend who had already watched it twice, and I enjoyed every second of it. The use of a meter slowly counting up to Mob's "Explosion" builds tension, even moreso as the series progresses and the stakes get higher.


OVERALL: 8


It's quirky, it's kick-butt, but more importantly, it has heart. We can sympathize with Shigeo's desire to be more popular (especially as a middle-schooler), and with Ritsu's desire to be more like his older brother. A lot of the rules of this universe seem to be hidden from us, and seem to be revealed only when they need to be. It's very mysterious, but it also likes to play around. It's great, even as a standalone thing, but I'm so looking forward to Season 2 in 2019.

Yikes, that was a mess. Mob Psycho 100 starts off similar to One Punch Man with its humour and superhero setting but reveals the story's more serious layer before long. The show starts off promising but unfortunately the quality goes downhill after 3-4 episodes as the end product becomes neither funny nor deep.. just edgy and uninteresting. The show can't decide whether it's taking itself seriously or not. Both the self-aware jokes and 'deep' ideas are just.. kind of out there without cohesion. Despite boasting character development, the villains either end up dead before they can be developed or are dull and one-dimensional. They mostlyserve as tools for the brother MCs. To be fair, there is only so much you can do in 12 episodes. I felt like this show was experimental in many ways, it tried to be different than the pack but the formula just didn't work. \n\n
On the plus side I enjoyed the artstyle and some of the fight scenes though these were also nothing to write home about. Reigen was a fun character to watch, his interactions were the highlights of the show. In conclusion, unless you're a ONE fan or you want to see Saitama wear different wigs, feel free to pass on this one.

Summing up Mob Psycho 100 in a sentence is: "Too good for its own sake"

Where is the 10/10 score?\n
The characters art... A bunch of the characters were...\n
Hey look! Is blonde exorcist saitama with short bowl head saitama! Look thats female photographer saitama! And here he comes the other blonde saitama to kick the ass of the bowl head saitama! Ugh...\n
I get that Mob and his brother look alike because they are brothers. But some other characters being literally Saitama with a wig was something unforgivable. Why? Because not all the characters are represented in that way. There are a lot of characters that are drawn completely different.\n
So its either everyone are Saitama with a wig or only 1 (maybe two if we count the brother in). Nothing in between is forgivable.\n
The last point: Pacing.\n
This anime goes fast. Ridiculously fast. \n
Crazy fast. A character can get a power up on an episode and be a complete monster on the next one.\n
To the common anime watcher this can be a good thing since they hate filler, backstory and so but i felt that this pacing was so good that it was bad.\n
In the end i ended up wanting more of this almost masterpiece. \n
The story barely starts in this anime so think of this as a preview to the real show. Just like Re:Zero.

Okay, so these are the basics and I'm not going to delve very deep into them -- strictly in terms of art and humor (and characters, somewhat), this anime is reminiscent of OPM, since the two were written by the same creator. Those are the aspects that stand out the most for me personally, and get a big yes from me. Laughs are granted, especially on account of two certain supporting characters that come in at different points in time.
What lowered my final score was the inconsistency of the story.
[SPOILER WATCH: I'M KEEPING IT AS VAGUE AS I CAN BELOW.]
It started to suffer about halfwaythrough the season -- just around the time Ritsu began to gain more focus, and even more so, specifically as soon as Mob & co. started to get *seemingly* closer to the real villains of the show... only for those villains' trail to become ACTUALLY increasingly confusing. If that sounds like it doesn't make sense, well, the story didn't help me out here much. That's essentially the key word to describe my thoughts on the latter half of the season -- confusion.\n\n
Let me recap what that final run of episodes is like -- one bad guy pops up after another, and all of them have their names and powers like the ones that came before, but there comes a point where there's so many of them, and they disappear almost as quickly as they are introduced, and so much is going on with all the shifts and turns and realizations happening in the meantime that it's hard to keep up, and on top of that you discover you're now really tired of the location (which is the one thing that doesn't change for the longest time once the characters reach a certain area, and that's a BAD thing), and somehow, suddenly, you find that you... just... don't care anymore. Which is disappointing as hell to realize, when you know you loved the first seven-or-so episodes so much you were totally ready to rate this thing a 9. (Was that paragraph exhausting to read, or what? I swear that is the same feeling you get watching those episodes.)\n\n
In view of my love for those earlier episodes as well as the characters, I can't give this less than a 7. There are also parts of the finale that worked for me, I guess (most did not). Still, it's a shame. I'm hoping season 2 pulls through, because this has a LOT of potential.

Made by the same guy who wrote OPM and it almost looks like he drew it as well. The plot is definitely different then OPM even though the MC of both are slightly emotionless and unimpressive at first.
Pros: Cool story line, and awesome skills.
Cons: Basic animations, nothing noteworthy on sounds.
~SPOILERS~
If you like the manga i really would recommend the anime, i do recommend reading the manga first as of now 08/02/2017(100 chp) it'll take about 2 weeks of daily reading. The use of good/great drawing sporadically used should also be a main stay of ONEs anime's, used for serious scenes or for a comedic punchat just the right time. Mob going 100% usually happens when he goes unconscious and usually a new "form" not apparent in the manga appears so we don't know if this is just Mob's nature or if he is possessed by something. But he has used it consciously in the manga a few times. Single watch is a definite, but multiple watches is only recommended for those who just love the series.

At the moment that One Punch Man came out, we were surprised with an original protagonist, a surprising plot, memorable characters and fights that are worth seeing again and again and it was all this that led me to want to know more about its creator, and I do not mean Yusuke Murata, whose art really brings Saitama to its fullest expression, but who conceived it. Under the pseudonym One, he brought this incredible story, but with a drawing quality well below average, but it was the great vision of this man that gave us Saitama and therefore Mob. Unlike the strongest bald man evercreated, Mob retains all his visual style based on One's manga, but at no time does he have to envy Saitama. Mob Psycho is a really great story that exploits another character of overwhelming power in search of more human goals, added to that to its somewhat bizarre animation, brings truly unique moments. A story that really is worthwhile.

There's plenty of great things in this anime, including one of the best intros imo. The story has a nice progression and pretty good world building. I adore super power anime so that's why it's not lower than 8 considering it seems to have some pretty lazily made characters (mostly antagonists) who just never seem satisfy more than an "ouuu shiny" response. It also seems to have a hard time building up the main antagonist(s) and just feels very superficial and forced to me. Imo, either make good characters that actually have importance or just leave them out, otherwise it's just noise that detracts fromwhat makes this anime so good.

I'm going to keep this review nice and simple.
Mob Psycho 100 no matter what anybody tells you is essentially One Punch Man but better. If you haven't seen One Punch Man, just imagine a strong fucking character that beats it's villain up but there's comedy.
Mob Psycho is a show full of espers. This show has redemption,kindness, and extremely colorful fights. A mc that's already powerful that can fuck up any egoistic villain really strokes your knob of excitement. The villain makes dumb jokes about how they'll destroy the mc only to get bop bop to the head and explode. If you don't find these typeof anime funny, at least give it a try. I find this repetitive as well but Mob Psycho does it so brilliantly you can't stop watching. It's not master piece but it aight cuh.\n\n
Progression Toward's Mob Explosion: 100%

A 12 episode series from the creator of One Punch Man. Yes, please. 
Mob Psycho 100 has a subtle hint of almost everything. There is supernatural, overly powerful protagonist who is gullible, a decent storyline, fight scenes are exciting, it has an element of morality and some ground realities.
I love the art style used in the anime itself. It gives a kiddish feeling and the not to forget Reigen reminds me so much of Onizuka. 
It's a short fun series. I am waiting if it will be renewed for the next season; ending implied it will get a second season.
7/10 from me.

I take in consideration that Mob Psycho 100 might just not be my thing although I loved One Punch Man from the same creator, but it's not really good. Maybe it just went over my head. There's this metaphor about people born with psychic powers aka "people who are special" that are greatly advantaged in life, just like our normal world where some people are extremely good at stuff and it advantages them more or less the same way. But they're also still human after all and luck is also a factor, just like real life. I think that's a good idea except you couldmake a compilation of all those dialogues in 5 minutes top. Twelve episodes is too long and too empty to pass this "theme" along and it just end up feeling like a boring, uninspired, ordinary shounen despite the unique artstyle and imagination of One.


Characters were pretty boring and lacked substance, except for Reigen, who is exceptional. He's a con artist that screw the metaphor over because he's good at lying and improvising. He doesn't need psychic powers if he can convince a client a ghost exist, he doesn't need powers to exorcise a fake ghost and if he stumble on a real problem, he already convinced arguably the most powerful esper in the world to be his student and employee. He is more interesting than the rest of the cast. The battles are lame too, expect one-sided battles all the time, except when it involves Shigeo/Mob. Then you have to be patient and wait until his counter reaches a hundred percent, then he goes from "I don't want to hurt anyone and I'm fine getting raped and destroyed" to "I'm invincible".


I don't want to be pretentious or tell people what they should like or not but all in all I feel this is overhyped, it's just not really good. Is it a cheap idea to cash in the success of One Punch Man? Who knows. It had potential, it just falls short. On a positive note, it's not a trash anime. I've disliked shows in the past because they were stinking too hard (Black Lagoon, Fullmetal Panic!, Psycho-pass, etc.) but this one doesn't stink. It's just not a ripe fruit.

Really wanted to enjoy this anime given that it was made by the creators of One Punch man and it had high ratings. However, unfortunately for me, I was very disappointed.
One of the main reasons was the art style. I just did not like it at all. I was hoping for it to grow onto me as the series went on but it never happened and it was a constant source of annoyance detracting from the story. However, many people seem to like the unique style so it might be just me so I would suggest giving it a go. Also, despite the art stylebeing bad the animation was a bit better and many scenes rolled out quite nicely.


Another reason was the characters. I just did not connect with the main character at all. Despite him being quite OP on a physical level, his personality was something I could not stand at all. He is very unemotional and just lacks any resemblance of common sense which makes him just frustrating to follow. The arbitrary restrictions of not using his powers on others imposed by his master also just felt very silly.


Regarding the story, it felt very episodic (maybe it was the intention) as opposed to there being a real plot behind it. I also did not like the exorcist element at all a) because it is a very lame concept in the first place imo and b)there was no uncertainty about any encounter ever since the viewer always knew that Mob could take care of the situation

(This review may contain spoiler and/or name drops of other anime and/or forms of media. This review is just personal opinion but may have factual reasons to back up certain parts of the opinion.)
Mob Psycho 100 is originally a web manga created by ONE (also created One Punch Man) that was adapted into an anime by Studio Bones. Of course, these two aspects caused a severe hype train among pretty much everyone in the anime community as both ONE and Bones are heavily admired. But for me, those two aspects were severe red flags considering that One Punch Man was a giant disaster of ananime and Bones made My Hero Academia, another giant disaster of an anime, the season before Mob Psycho 100 aired. And looking at Bones' history, they were quite an awful studio in my eyes, as they have also made rather hideous drecks like Fullmetal Alchemist (and Brotherhood), Soul Eater, Space Dandy, Noragami, and many more. Unsurprisingly, I didn't stand corrected and I got just what I expected but even worse; a hideous dreck blown to extreme proportions. 


Story - 1/10: 


There really is no saving the storyline here. First, there is this guy named Shigeo Kageyama, a.k.a. Mob, who is an esper with psychic powers and joins Arataka Reigen, who is a conman when it comes to hunting ghosts, and they go on a hunting spree. However, they try to expand it to Mob being ostracized for his esper powers but next thing you know, he makes friends in an instant, nullifying the esper ostracization that might have had the story something to go for. To make matters worse, it is being praised for literally being the antithesis of The Irregular At Magic High School, which is often called out for turning into a harem (of course harems are the biggest scapegoats in regards to anime). Overall, the story just blows and there is no saving this one, but the next aspect is EVEN WORSE!


Art - (-5/10):


Yeah, I seriously have to give negative points on the art department because Mob Psycho is by far one of, if not, the most hideous anime I have ever seen, on par with Masaaki Yuasa's works, both in terms of the art style and character designs. And of course, it's not shocking that LITERALLY EVERYTHING IN THE ANIME IS HAND DRAWN, which is the main reason why it's so hideous in the first place. And don't get me started on character designs. ONE's drawings are as bad as they were in One Punch Man, and literally every human being in the anime is a bunch of Saitama clones with wigs (as if Saitama's character design wasn't bad enough)! Seriously, do ONE and Studio Bones seriously hate modern art styles? These seriously make them comes off as a yes to the question, and I won't be surprised if it actually is true. Sadly, it is being praised exactly for that, cutting corners heavily and abstaining from the use of modern technology. And I don't want to feel like I am watching a terribly old anime when watching a modern anime. But this does exactly that in one of the strongest manners possible. So yeah, one of the worst art I have ever seen in all of anime, so bad it was terribly nauseating.


Sound - 3/10:


You know, I will give where it's due. The OP, 99, and ED, Refrain Boy, don't sound all that bad. However, that's not saying they're any good at all. Those are just average at best. The rest of the soundtrack isn't worth mentioning as they're just forgettable. 


Character - 1/10: 


Ah, the awful world of characters. Mob, the unsatisfied idiot who is terribly nonbadass (ONE's signature move for MC characters, unsurprisingly), Reigen, the conman who walks away scat free, Koyama, a cookie cutter villain who gets praise solely for being in a Studio Bones shonen anime, and a bunch of other character I already stopped caring about now.


Enjoyment - 0/10: 


what sort of enjoyment is there, when there is a combination of piss poor storyline, hideously offensive and/or nauseating art style and character designs, average-at-best OP and Ed best forgettable rest of soundtrack, and overall just straight up bad and forgettable characters? For me, there is zero enjoyment and I for one cannot recommend anyone to watch this and become elitists. 


Overall - 0/10: 


All in all, One Punch Man, Mob Psycho 100, and My Hero Academia combined was the death sentence of anime I considered good, as I am constantly running out of anime that interest me. I cannot endorse this at all and I have to consider this as one of, if not, the worst anime I have ever seen in my life.
